biographical_notes:
Born Lydia Liliʻu Loloku Walania Kamakaʻeha on September 2, 1838, in Honolulu, Oʻahu. Parents: father Caesar Kapaʻakea, mother Analea Keohokālole. She was hānai-adopted by Abner Pākī and Laura Kōnia. Education: educated at the Royal School in Honolulu among other high chiefs. Proficient in Western and Hawaiian cultural learning.
Musical contributions: • Composed over 150 songs and chants across genres: traditional mele, hymns, ballads, waltzes. • Instruments she played: piano, organ, guitar, autoharp. Also sang and served as choir director. • Famous works include "Aloha ʻOe", "He Mele Lāhui Hawaiʻi", "By And By, Hoʻi Mai ʻOe", among others. • Many compositions reflect Hawaiian history, nature, love, loss, and political themes. During her imprisonment (after overthrow of monarchy) she continued composing, including "The Queen's Prayer" (Ke Aloha O Ka Haku).
notable_works: By And By Hoʻi Mai ʻOe
